articles.headline: With Dry Taps and Toilets, California Drought Turns Desperate
articles.snippet: In Tulare County, hit hard by a relentless drought, daily routines have been upended by the drying of wells and the disappearance of tap water.
articles.abstract: In Tulare County, hit hard by a relentless drought, daily routines have been upended by the drying of wells and the disappearance of tap water.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORTERVILLE, Calif. — After a nine-hour day working at a citrus packing plant, her body covered in a sheen of fruit wax and dust, there is nothing Angelica Gallegos wants more than a hot shower, with steam to help clear her throat and lungs.

articles.headline: JPMorgan Chase Hacking Affects 76 Million Households
articles.snippet: The disclosure by the bank dwarfs earlier estimates that attackers had gained access to roughly one million customer accounts.
articles.abstract: The disclosure by the bank dwarfs earlier estimates that attackers had gained access to roughly one million customer accounts.
articles.lead_paragraph: A cyberattack this summer on JPMorgan Chase compromised the accounts of 76 million households and seven million small businesses, a tally that dwarfs previous estimates by the bank and puts the intrusion among the largest ever.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg, Matthew Goldstein and Nicole Perlroth

articles.headline: Facebook Promises Deeper Review of User Research, but Is Short on the Particulars
articles.snippet: The social media company said that it would more strictly review its research practices, though it didn’t quite offer how.
articles.abstract: The social media company said that it would more strictly review its research practices, though it didn’t quite offer how.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook said on Thursday that future research on its 1.3 billion users would be subjected to greater internal scrutiny from top managers, particularly if it focused on “deeply personal topics” or specific groups of people.

articles.headline: Why Ben Bernanke Can’t Refinance His Mortgage
articles.snippet: The former Fed chairman’s mortgage problem may highlight the surprises an automated mortgage system can deliver on eligibility.
articles.abstract: The former Fed chairman’s mortgage problem may highlight the surprises an automated mortgage system can deliver on eligibility.
articles.lead_paragraph: An employee of a think tank owns a house in the Capitol Hill neighborhood of Washington. He wants to refinance his mortgage, but the bank won’t give him a loan.

articles.headline: Overseas Stimulus Moves Drive Yen, Euro and Renminbi Down Against Dollar
articles.snippet: As the Federal Reserve winds down its own stimulus campaign, central banks elsewhere are moving in the other direction, a trend likely to intensify.
articles.abstract: As the Federal Reserve winds down its own stimulus campaign, central banks elsewhere are moving in the other direction, a trend likely to intensify.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the growth of the United States economy outstrips the rest of the developed world, American policy makers are allowing Europe, Japan and even China to seek a little more prosperity — at the expense of Americans.
articles.byline: By Binyamin Appelbaum, Jack Ewing and Neil Gough

articles.headline: Decision Allows Abortion Law, Forcing 13 Texas Clinics to Close
articles.snippet: In Texas’s long legal battle over its sweeping abortion law, an appeals court gave the state permission to require clinics to meet the same standards as hospital-style surgical centers.
articles.abstract: In Texas’s long legal battle over its sweeping abortion law, an appeals court gave the state permission to require clinics to meet the same standards as hospital-style surgical centers.
articles.lead_paragraph: DALLAS — Thirteen abortion clinics in Texas were forced to close immediately after a federal appellate court on Thursday sided with Texas in its yearlong legal battle over its sweeping abortion law and allowed the state to enforce one of the law’s toughest provisions while the case was being appealed.

articles.headline: U.S. Aid Effort in Liberia Barely Off the Ground as Ebola Rages
articles.snippet: The American promise to build 18 Ebola treatment centers has been stalled by, among other things, broken equipment and numerous holes on an airport runway.
articles.abstract: The American promise to build 18 Ebola treatment centers has been stalled by, among other things, broken equipment and numerous holes on an airport runway.
articles.lead_paragraph: MONROVIA, Liberia — In the furious battle against time and a rampaging Ebola epidemic, the gravel crusher joined a long list of enemies.

articles.headline: Financial Ties Between Doctors and Health Care Firms Are Detailed
articles.snippet: In five months at the end of last year, doctors and other health care professionals made more than $212 million on speaking and consulting engagements for drug and device makers.
articles.abstract: In five months at the end of last year, doctors and other health care professionals made more than $212 million on speaking and consulting engagements for drug and device makers.
articles.lead_paragraph: For some doctors, treating patients isn’t the only way to make money.
articles.byline: By Katie Thomas and Rachel Abrams

articles.headline: Secret Goldman Sachs Tapes Put Pressure on New York Fed
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York, which regulates Wall Street’s largest banks, faces scrutiny from Congress after the release of an employee’s secret recordings that suggest lax oversight.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York, which regulates Wall Street’s largest banks, faces scrutiny from Congress after the release of an employee’s secret recordings that suggest lax oversight.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wall Street’s top regulator is coming under new criticism for failing to adequately police the banks under its supervision, years after the financial crisis.
articles.byline: By Nathaniel Popper and Peter Eavis

articles.headline: Some Blacks See Secret Service as Flawed Shield for the President
articles.snippet: The furor that led to the Secret Service chief’s resignation resonated among blacks who suspect that security lapses may be deliberate.
articles.abstract: The furor that led to the Secret Service chief’s resignation resonated among blacks who suspect that security lapses may be deliberate.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Elijah E. Cummings of Maryland was at the grocery store the other day when he ran into an elderly black woman who expressed growing concern about President Obama’s safety. Why, she asked, wasn’t he being better protected by his Secret Service agents?

articles.headline: Violence Erupts in Hong Kong as Protesters Are Assaulted
articles.snippet: Protesters in several districts came under attack on Friday from men seeking to break apart their sit-ins, tearing down tents and surrounding demonstrators.
articles.abstract: Protesters in several districts came under attack on Friday from men seeking to break apart their sit-ins, tearing down tents and surrounding demonstrators.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Pro-democracy demonstrations in two of Hong Kong’s most crowded shopping districts came under attack on Friday from unidentified men who assaulted protesters and tore down their encampments, after a week of erratic and unsuccessful attempts by the Beijing-backed government to end the protests.
articles.byline: By Chris Buckley, Austin Ramzy and Edward Wong

articles.headline: Jobless Rate in U.S. Falls Below 6% as Hiring Picks Up
articles.snippet: A surprisingly rosy jobs report appeared to be too little, too late for Democrats in struggling midterm campaigns.
articles.abstract: A surprisingly rosy jobs report appeared to be too little, too late for Democrats in struggling midterm campaigns.
articles.lead_paragraph: Five years after the nation emerged from a crippling recession, the economy finally appears to be on track for a more robust recovery, bolstered by strong recent job gains and an unemployment rate that dipped below 6 percent in September for the first time since the summer of 2008.
articles.byline: By Dionne Searcey and Jonathan Weisman

articles.headline: Why Is First Lady Scarce in Campaign? Her Last Name Is Obama
articles.snippet: Mrs. Obama, unlike Hillary Rodham Clinton in 1998, will keep to a fairly limited path as she stumps for candidates, some of whom are trying to distance themselves from the president.
articles.abstract: Mrs. Obama, unlike Hillary Rodham Clinton in 1998, will keep to a fairly limited path as she stumps for candidates, some of whom are trying to distance themselves from the president.
articles.lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — She can rouse a crowd as she did here this week, connect with women and drive turnout among African-American voters. Yet despite the nail-biting closeness of state contests to decide which party will control the Senate, Michelle Obama has been largely absent from the campaign trail so far.
